Code
BSBC.Data <- read.csv("C:/Users/betsy/OneDrive/Desktop/Master's Degree/BSBC Data.csv")
 View(BSBC.Data)
 
 df_long1 <- BSBC.Data %>%
   select(Region,BF.2018,BF.2020,BF.2022) %>%
   pivot_longer(cols = c(BF.2018,BF.2020,BF.2022),
                names_to = "Year",
                values_to = "BF",
                names_prefix = "BF.")

df_long <- BSBC.Data %>%
  rename(BF.at.6.months.2022=BF.at.6.months..2022) %>%
  select(State,BF.at.6.months.2018, BF.at.6.months.2020, BF.at.6.months.2022) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(BF.at.6.months.2018, BF.at.6.months.2020, BF.at.6.months.2022),  # Replace with your column names
    names_to = "year",
    values_to = "BF", 
    names_prefix = "BF.at.6.months."
  )

title: “ASSIGNMENT 4”
text:
Expressiveness and Effectiveness
Figure. 1


Code
ggplot(df_long1, aes(x=Region,y=BF))+
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", aes(fill=Region)) +
  xlab("WIC Region") +
  ylab("BF Rate at 6 months (percent)") +
  ggtitle("BF rate by WIC Region") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5, size = 0.1),
        legend.position = "right")+
  facet_wrap(~Year)


Warning: Removed 126 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_bar()`).









Figure 2. What needs to be expressed here is expressed; Rates of breastfeeding at 6 months by state and it adds in years… However, the effectiveness is horrible. There is way too much going on and it is hard to follow and determine what is what. It really needs to be separate graphs, or separated by region instead of state or something to make it more clear and concise.


Code
ggplot(df_long, aes(x=State,y=BF))+
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", aes(fill=State, alpha=year)) +
  xlab("State") +
  ylab("BF Rate at 6 months (percent") +
  ggtitle("BF rate by state") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5, size = 0.1),
        legend.position = "right")


Warning: Using alpha for a discrete variable is not advised.

title: “ASSIGNMENT 4”
text:
Discriminability
Figure 3. Box and Whisker allows you to see outliers more easily. It also is just an easy way to see values, and is just overall very clean and easy to discern.


Code
ggplot(data=df_long, aes(y=BF, x=year)) +
  geom_boxplot() + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  labs( title = "Distribution of BF by Year", x = "Year", y = "BF Value" )









Figure 4. This is unnecessary addition of color that doesn’t really add to the discernability.


Code
ggplot(data=df_long, aes(y=BF, x=year)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill= c("red", "blue", "green"))

title: “ASSIGNMENT 4”
text:
Seperability
I feel like Figures 1 & 2 are good examples of this as well, so I am repeating them in this section:


Code
ggplot(df_long1, aes(x=Region,y=BF))+
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", aes(fill=Region)) +
  xlab("WIC Region") +
  ylab("BF Rate at 6 months (percent)") +
  ggtitle("BF rate by WIC Region") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5, size = 0.1),
        legend.position = "right")+
  facet_wrap(~Year)


Warning: Removed 126 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_bar()`).









Code
ggplot(df_long, aes(x=State,y=BF))+
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", aes(fill=State, alpha=year)) +
  xlab("State") +
  ylab("BF Rate at 6 months (percent") +
  ggtitle("BF rate by state") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5, size = 0.1),
        legend.position = "right")


Warning: Using alpha for a discrete variable is not advised.









##PopOut
I made it so that Alabama breastfeeding data from 2018 stood out as a red dot.


Code
r1<-subset(BSBC.Data, State=="Alabama" )
ggplot(df_long1, aes(x=Year, y=BF))+
  geom_point() +
  theme_minimal()+
   geom_point(data = r1, aes(x=State, y =BF.at.6.months.2018),
             color = "red")


Warning: Removed 126 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).

title: Assignment 1
text:
Tidied up

tidy_anscombe <- anscombe %>%
 pivot_longer(cols = everything(),
              names_to = c(".value", "set"),
              names_pattern = "(.)(.)")
tidy_anscombe_summary <- tidy_anscombe %>%
  group_by(set) %>%
  summarise(across(.cols = everything(),
                   .fns = lst(min,max,median,mean,sd,var),
                   .names = "{col}_{fn}"))
#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)

vars<-c("set", "x_mean", "x_var",  "y_mean", "y_var")
thing<- as.data.frame(tidy_anscombe_summary[vars])
knitr::kable(thing)

x_mean
x_var
y_mean

title: Assignment 1
text:
Why Visualization Matters

ggplot(tidy_anscombe,
       aes(x = x,
           y = y)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_point(data = tidy_anscombe_summary, aes(x=x_mean, y = y_mean, color = "red", size = 5),
             show.legend = FALSE)+
  facet_wrap(~set) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Betsy Church
text:
https://linkedin.com
https://github.com
Betsy Church is a Graduate Student at University of Idaho. Current research project is about the potential effects that a Staph. aureus infection may have on the tissue and secretion microbiomes of artificially induced lactation in heifers. When not in the lab, she can be found crocheting, watching medical drama on tv, or playing video games. Often times, her dog Finn or Cat Olivander can be found snuggled in her lap.

Weber State University | Ogden, UT
Bachelor of Science in Microbiology | August 2016- April 2021

title: Assignment 2
text:
Description of Data Set
This data set is tabular data and the attribute is categorical/quantitative. The data includes the breastfeeding rates (in %) of each state and the mPINC scores (algorithmic data) of each state. I have also included the breastfeeding rates of the different regions, based off of WIC regions. These all are from the year 2018,2020, and 2022.
